item.title: Can You Play Kirby Air Riders On Switch 1? Nintendo Switch 2 & Switch 1 Status, Explained
item.content:encoded:
Kirby Air Riders could end up being one of the sleeper hits of 2025 for Nintendo, and if you’re a Switch or Switch 2 user eager to know if everyone’s small, round, pink cutie is coming to old-gen or current-gen hardware, you’ve raced into the right place.

Since day one, the differentiation between games, hardware, updates, and other issues has been unclear for the Nintendo Switch and its Switch 2 successor. It’s like this will continue for several years yet. This is where we come in to tell you which pit lane you need to go to for Kirby Air Riders.

The spiritual successor to 2003’s Kirby Air Riders has a lot of competition to catch up.

Can You Play Kirby Air Riders On Nintendo Switch 2?

Kirby Air Riders is most definitely launching on the Nintendo Switch 2 when its November 20 release date finally arrives.

The Switch 2 has had a decent amount of exclusives in its first year. Mario Kart World, Donkey Kong Bananza, and the upcoming Metroid Prime 4: Beyond are system-selling starlets. But Nintendo isn’t content with this, which is why we’re getting another exclusive—and another racer at that.

You could say Kirby Air Riders isn’t the type of game everyone has been crying out for, but we won’t say no. It should provide competition and another option to Nintendo racing fans. The main thing that wasn’t in doubt was the game releasing on the Nintendo Switch 2, though.

Can You Play Kirby Air Riders On Nintendo Switch 1?

You can’t buy and play Kirby Air Riders on the OG Nintendo Switch, making it a Switch 2 exclusive.

A Switch 2 port was never in doubt, but the original Nintendo Switch was touch-and-go. We’re already sensing a theme with big-time Nintendo exclusives—Metroid Prime 4 aside. The old-gen hardware has served its purpose and attracted well over 150 million buyers. Now, the race is on for Switch 2 to surpass the device it succeeded.

How do you do this? By restricting the availability of shiny new Nintendo titles. Kirby Air Riders is only coming to Nintendo Switch 2, which means if you’re keen to ride the airy waves, you need to make a Kirby-sized jump to the Switch 2.

Is Kirby Air Riders On Any Other Platform?

Kirby Air Riders isn’t coming to PlayStation, Xbox, or PC; it’s only available on the Nintendo Switch 2.

We thought we’d address this question quickly, especially in this day and age of exclusives and first-party titles flying here, there, and everywhere. Kirby Air Riders is coming to Switch 2 and nothing else.

Are you excited for Kirby Air Riders? Can it be a force in the kart-racing genre, battling Mario Kart, Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds, and others? You know what to do: Go to the Insider Gaming Discord Server and let us know what you think of the game and if it has potential.

item.title: Today’s Wordle #1610: Hints And Answer For November 15, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Wordle challenges players to guess a fresh five-letter word each day in six tries or fewer. Whether you’re a beginner or a daily player, today’s tips and strategies can help you solve it faster and maintain your streak—if you’re open to a little extra help. So, if you’ve found yourself stuck with today’s Wordle, don’t worry, below you’ll find some helpful hints and even the answer for Wordle Game #1610 for November 15, 2025.

To play today’s Wordle, head to the game’s website. If you want to go right to today’s answer without any tips or tricks, you can click right here. If you’ve missed any days, check out our Wordle Answer Archive for every past answer.

IMPORTANT: The following information includes spoilers on today’s and yesterday’s editions of Wordle. If you don’t want the answer given to you, stop scrolling.

How To Play Wordle

Wordle is a simple but addictive word puzzle. Each day, players have to guess a five-letter word answer in no more than six attempts. After each guess:

  • Green letters are correct and in the right position.
  • Yellow letters are correct, but in the wrong position.
  • Gray letters are not in the word at all.

The goal is to guess the word in as few tries as possible. Daily puzzles keep players coming back for more, making it a fun brain exercise and a popular online trend.

Wordle can only be played on the New York Times website. There is currently no app for you to download the official game.

Wordle Hints For Today, November 15, 2025

The Wordle answer for game #1610 might give some players a bit of a challenge. According to the NY Times Wordle review, today’s answer takes an average of 4.3 of 6 guesses. That makes it just a bit harder than the 4 guess average from November 14.

General Wordle Hints For November 15

Without giving today’s Wordle answer completely away, here are a few helpful hints for today to get you started:

  • Hint 1: The word uses only one vowel
  • Hint 2: It ends with a hard consonant sound.
  • Hint 3: It can be paired with another verb to describe something happening suddenly or tightly.
  • Hint 4: The word is related in form to actions that involve grip or attachment.

Use these clues to narrow down your guesses and increase your chances of solving Wordle #1610 for November 15, 2025

Starter Words For November 15, 2025

If you want help getting started without having today’s Wordle answer given to you, there are a few starter words worth trying that will help you figure out some included letters. A few starter words that may help are:

  • LUNAR
  • CLING
  • FLUNG

Today’s Wordle Answer For Game #1610 On November 15, 2025

If you’ve tried everything, including using the above hints, and are still stuck, you can find the answer to today’s Wordle below.

Answer: CLUNG

If you solved today’s Wordle without our answer, congratulations! If not, take note of the best tips above for tomorrow’s puzzle, and check back daily for more hints.

What Does Today’s Wordle Answer Mean?

Clung is a pretty common word that means to “hold on tightly to”. It’s the past tense and past participle of cling.

Yesterday’s Wordle Answer

If you missed the previous game, here’s yesterday’s Wordle answer for Game #1609 on November 14, 2025:

Answer: LURID

While not always the case, looking at previous words can sometimes give you insight into common patterns or letter usage in Wordle puzzles. Reminder, you can check out every past Wordle answer in our official archive.

When Is The Next Wordle Game After #1610?

Wordle games are updated daily at 12 am or Midnight in your respective time zone. Information about the next game is often available in the hours before to give players a heads up. The game on November 16 will be Wordle Game #1611.

What Is Wordle?

Wordle is a daily word puzzle created by Josh Wardle. Initially developed as a prototype in 2013, it wasn’t fully released until 2021. The game challenges players to guess a five-letter word in six tries or fewer, using hints from each attempt to narrow down the answer. Its straightforward concept, accessibility, and the thrill of solving a new puzzle each day helped it surge in popularity by late 2021. The success of Wordle inspired numerous spin-offs and social media challenges, leading to its acquisition by The New York Times in early 2022.

item.title: EXCLUSIVE: Dying Light: Hellrunners—The Zombie Game That Never Made It
item.content:encoded:
Dying Light fans have been enjoying The Beast since mid-September, and thanks to updates made by Techland, it’s proving to be a gift that keeps on giving. In case you’re uninitiated with The Beast, the game effectively sets up the next generation of Dying Light, an open-world zombie slasher title that has existed since 2015.

However, not every Dying Light game ever concocted has made it to the market. In 2015, the Techland team released Dying Light, then in 2022 came Dying Light 2: Stay Human. But between those games sat a whole array of concept titles, and one in particular would have been a total genre pivot for fans of the relatively new franchise.

Dying Light: Hellrunners Laid to Rest

Between 2016 and 2017, the team at Techland was busy innovating in the Dying Light space, and one title that came out of the creative minds of those at the firm was Dying Light: Hellrunners.

Hellrunners would have been a ‘runner’; a game that typically uses procedural generation or a never-ending loop to permit the player to, you guessed it, run forever. As the player traverses an endless pathway, they’re faced with obstacles to repeatedly overcome while securing points, coins, tokens, or something else entirely.

However, Techland was quick to point out that the endless approach was just one angle, and that the team was also trying out a ‘level-based’ approach.

Think of a game like Canabalt, a horizontally-scrolling endless runner, but add in nicer graphics, is what I was told. Then, throw in the undead and some parkour mechanics, and you’re probably close to picturing Dying Light: Hellrunners.

I caught up with Techland’s Tymon Smektala, Franchise Director, to learn more about Hellrunners and why the game never saw the light of day:

We experimented with a runner DL game but after some prototypes realized that there’s not much we can do to make it stand out or innovate within the genre.

With that, Hellrunners was shelved, never to be revisited, and the team moved on to piece together Dying Light 2: Stay Human.

Being a Dying Light fan, I was curious to learn if there were any relations between ‘Hellrunners’ and ‘Nightrunners’, the faction that exists within Villedor in Dying Light 2: Stay Human.

There was no connection between Hellrunners and Nightrunners – Nightrunners were conceptualized later in the production of Dying Light 2: Stay Human, long when Hellrunners was altogether scrapped.

It’s easy to imagine Dying Light: Hellrunners as a pretty gnarly mobile game. Runners are still pretty popular today, but they’re mostly hyper-casual experiences that offer little in the way of gameplay depth and are mostly time-killer titles.

I could just picture Dying Light: Hellrunners, though. I can imagine obstacles being items to vault or leap over, gaps that need to be crossed with a well-timed grapple hook, and undead lumbering in your path that need to be struck down as you run, all while you collect UV bars, coins, or vials of Antizin.

Do you wish Dying Light: Hellrunners had been made in the end? Let me know what you’re thinking on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Horizon Steel Frontiers Isn’t the Only Horizon Multiplayer Game Coming
item.content:encoded:
NCSoft’s and PlayStation’s Horizon Steel Frontiers is not the only multiplayer game on the horizon; Guerrilla Games has something cooking in this space as well.

For those unaware, Horizon Steel Frontiers is a new MMORPG that was revealed yesterday. It is launching for PC and mobile devices, but we do not have a release date yet. Also, a new interview recently revealed that AI was used ‘extensively‘ in the development process of the upcoming multiplayer game.

Guerrilla’s Horizon Multiplayer Title is their ‘Next Big Project’

The clarification about Guerrilla’s Horizon multiplayer title came through a post by Jason Schreier on BlueSky. Schreir stated, “Just to clear up some confusion I’ve seen,’ Horizon Steel Frontiers’ from NCSoft is different from the multiplayer Horizon game that’s in development at Guerrilla Games.” Schreier added that Guerrilla Games’ upcoming Horizon multiplayer title is their “next big project”. He also thinks that NCSoft’s MMO is “meant for Asian markets”.

The Horizon franchise has been in the news a lot lately. Earlier this year, it was all about Sony’s Horizon clone lawsuit against Tencent for the latter’s upcoming title, Light of Motiram. Then the focus shifted to NCSoft and PlayStation’s Horizon Steel Frontiers, which dropped an over 10-minute video revealing some gameplay and other elements of the title. And now, we have been informed that another Horizon multiplayer game is on the way; it seems the series fans have a lot to look forward to in the coming years.

In other news, court documents have revealed that the Horizon Zero Dawn movie is planned to release in 2027. Additionally, Tencent recently responded to the lawsuit, stating, “fame doesn’t create a trademark.” What are your thoughts on another Horizon multiplayer game being worked on by Guerrilla Games?
